revisions.rev:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Amy Poehler | image = Amy Poehler 2011 Shankbone 2.JPG | imagesize = | caption = Poehler at the 2011 [[Time 100]] gala | pseudonym = | birthname = Amy Meredith Poehler | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|9|16}} | birth_place = [[Newton, Massachusetts]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Actress, voice actress, comedian, writer, producer | yearsactive = 1977âpresent | spouse = [[Will Arnett]] (2003-present; 2 children) | domesticpartner = | website = }} '''Amy Meredith Poehler''' {{IPAc-en|icon|Ë|p|oÊ|l|Ér}} (born September 16, 1971) is an American comedian, actress and voice actress. She was a cast member on the [[NBC]] television entertainment show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' from 2001 to 2008. In 2004, she starred in the film ''[[Mean Girls]]'' with [[Tina Fey]], with whom she worked again in ''[[Baby Mama (film)|Baby Mama]]'' in 2008. She is currently the lead of [[NBC]]'s comedy ''[[Parks and Recreation]]''. She has been nominated twice for both the [[Primetime Emmy Award]] for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series for her performance on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', and for the Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series for her performance in ''Parks & Recreation''. ==Early life== Poehler was born in [[Newton, Massachusetts]], and grew up in [[Burlington, Massachusetts]]. She is the daughter of Eileen Frances (nÃ©e Milmore) and William Grinstead Poehler, both teachers.Stated in interview on ''[[Inside the Actors Studio]]'', 2009 She is a distant cousin of author [[Stephen King]] and U.S. senator [[Scott Brown]], through shared [[New England]] ancestry.[http://www.americanancestors.org/uploadedFiles/American_Ancestors/Content/Blogs/NEHGS_News/Poehler_king.pdf][http://www.americanancestors.org/uploadedFiles/American_Ancestors/Content/Blogs/NEHGS_News/Poehler_brown.pdf][http://www.americanancestors.org/Blogs.aspx?id=21719&blogid=98434 "Burlington, MA Native Amy Poehler has Interesting Family Ties"] October 13, 2010, Blogg at American Ancestors web site Poehler was raised Catholic. A 1993 graduate of [[Boston College]], Poehler was a member of America's oldest collegiate [[Improvisational theatre|improv]] comedy troupe, "My Mother's Fleabag". After graduating from college, Poehler moved to [[Chicago]], where she studied [[improvisational theatre]] at [[The Second City|Second City]], with friend and future co-star [[Tina Fey]]. She also studied with [[Del Close]] at [[ImprovOlympic]], going on to become part of the touring company as well as teaching classes at IO.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} ==Career== ===''Upright Citizens Brigade'' === During her time at Second City, Poehler studied with [[Matt Besser]], part of the [[Upright Citizens Brigade]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} While the group initially consisted of many members (including [[Horatio Sanz]], [[Adam McKay]], [[Rick Roman]], and [[Neil Flynn]]), Poehler quickly became part of the group along with [[Matt Walsh (comedian)|Matt Walsh]]. The two, along with Besser and [[Ian Roberts (actor)|Ian Roberts]], performed sketch and improv around Chicago before moving to New York in 1996. Immediately after moving to New York, the group quickly scored a TV gig,{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} appearing as sketch regulars on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]''. In 1998, [[Comedy Central]] debuted the group's eponymous half-hour sketch comedy series.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} During the show's second season, the group opened an Improv theatre and training center in New York City at 161 W. 22nd Street, occupying the space of a former strip club.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} The UCB theatre held shows seven nights a week in addition to offering classes in [[sketch comedy]] writing and improv. In the summer of 2000, Comedy Central canceled the ''Upright Citizens Brigade'' program after its third season, though the UCB Theatre continues to operate.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} The foursome continue to work together in many projects, and frequently perform together in live improv shows at their comedy theatres in NY and LA.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} ===''Saturday Night Live''=== Poehler joined the cast of ''SNL'' during the [[Saturday Night Live (season 27)|2001â02 season]], her debut episode being the first one produced after the [[9/11 attacks]] â with host [[Reese Witherspoon]], musical guest [[Alicia Keys]], and New York City Mayor [[Rudy Giuliani]] as a special guest.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Poehler was promoted from featured player to full cast member in her first season on the show, making her only the third person to have earned this distinction (after [[Harry Shearer]] and [[Eddie Murphy]]).[http://www.actressarchives.com/news.php?id=10357 Amy Poehler News | Amy Poehler is Real Life Baby Mama] Beginning with the [[Saturday Night Live (season 30)|2004â05 season]], she co-anchored "[[Weekend Update]]" with Tina Fey, replacing the newly departed [[Jimmy Fallon]]. In a ''[[TV Guide]]'' interview, Fey said that with Poehler co-anchoring, there now is "double the sexual tension." When Fey left after the [[Saturday Night Live (season 31)|2005â06 season]] to devote time to the sitcom she created, ''[[30 Rock]]'', [[Seth Meyers]] joined Poehler at the anchor desk. Poehler was nominated for a 2008 ''[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress â Comedy Series]]''[http://www.emmys.com/celebrities/amy-poehler Amy Poehler Emmy Nominated], the first ''SNL'' cast member recognized in this category.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} She was heavily favored to win by many critics, but ultimately lost to [[Jean Smart]]. She was nominated once again in 2009, but lost to [[Kristin Chenoweth]]. On September 13, 2008, the ''SNL'' season premiere opened with Fey and Poehler as [[Sarah Palin]] and [[Hillary Rodham Clinton|Hillary Clinton]], respectively, performing a "[[A Nonpartisan Message from Governor Sarah Palin & Senator Hillary Clinton|joint political campaign spot]]." It was officially announced on September 16, 2008 that Poehler would be leaving ''SNL'' in October due to the birth of her child.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} On the October 25, 2008 episode, it was announced by "Weekend Update" co-anchor [[Seth Meyers]], who anchored the segment alone, "Amy Poehler is not here because she is having a baby", to wild applause from the audience. At the end of "Weekend Update", special guest [[Maya Rudolph]] and current cast member [[Kenan Thompson]] sang a custom rendition of "[[Can't Take My Eyes Off You]]" for Poehler, changing the words: "We love you Amy, and we just can't wait to meet your baby!" Meyers signed off: "For Weekend Update, I'm Seth Meyers â we love you Amy!"{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} [[Image:SNL Palin Clinton.png|thumb|Web promo for 2008 web video of Palin (Fey) and Clinton (Poehler) from NBC.com.]] Poehler returned to the show on November 3, 2008, during the "''SNL'' Presidential Bash '08", "hosting" as Hillary Clinton. The Bash was pre-taped from scenes shot between September and October. Her return to ''SNL'' after her pregnancy was on December 6, 2008, where she stayed for two weeks.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} During "Weekend Update", on December 13, she thanked her family, friends, and fans for the continued support and announced that it would be her last show.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} On April 18, 2009, a ''Saturday Night Live'' special, "The Best of Amy Poehler", aired.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Poehler returned for "Weekend Update" (signing off with "...and he's Seth Meyers") and joined the "chorus" for [[Will Ferrell]]'s "Goodnight Saigon" (along with the ''SNL'' cast and [[Tom Hanks]], [[Maya Rudolph]], [[Norm Macdonald]], [[Artie Lange]], [[Anne Hathaway (actress)|Anne Hathaway]], and [[Green Day]]) on the ''SNL'' season finale on May 16, 2009.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Poehler returned to the "Weekend Update" desk in the fall of 2009 with Meyers, for two "WU" [[Weekend Update#Seth Meyers & (temporarily) Amy Poehler (2009âpresent)|Thursday episodes]], which led directly into ''[[Parks and Recreation]]''.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Poehler also returned to ''Saturday Night Live'' for a special [[Mother's Day]] episode on May 8, 2010, hosted by [[Betty White]].[http://www.broadwayworld.com/videoplay.php?colid=129095 STAGE TUBE: New Betty White SNL Promo! (TV Content)] Poehler returned to ''Saturday Night Live'' on September 25, 2010 to host the Season 36 opening episode with performer [[Katy Perry]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} She returned once again for the ''Saturday Night Live'' special, "The Women of ''SNL''". The special aired on November 1, 2010.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} ===''Parks and Recreation''=== In July 2008, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reported that Poehler was in final negotiations to star in a series by writers [[Greg Daniels]] and [[Mike Schur]], set to air on Thursdays before ''The Office'', starting January 2009 on [[NBC]].{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117989011.html?categoryid=14&cs=1|title=Poehler to join post-'Office' show|last=Schneidler|first=Michael|date=July 15, 2008|work=Variety |accessdate=August 15, 2008}} On July 21, 2008, NBC officially announced Poehler's new series, ''[[Parks & Recreation (TV series)|Parks and Recreation]]'', saying the project would not be a direct spin-off of ''The Office'', as previously speculated.{{cite web|url=http://livefeed.hollywoodreporter.com/2008/07/nbc-wants-both.html|title=NBC wants both a Poehler show and an 'Office' spin-off|date=July 21, 2008|work=THR Feed.com|accessdate=August 15, 2008}} Poehler joined an ensemble cast including [[Aziz Ansari]], [[Rashida Jones]], [[Chris Pratt]], [[Aubrey Plaza]], [[Paul Schneider (actor)|Paul Schneider]], [[Nick Offerman]], [[Adam Scott (actor)|Adam Scott]], and [[Rob Lowe]]. Poehler plays Deputy Director of the Parks Department, [Leslie Knope], in the fictional city of Pawnee, Indiana. After a rough [[Parks and Recreation (season 1)|first season]], the show's [[Parks and Recreation (season 2)|second season]] and [[Parks and Recreation (season 3)|third season]] have been well received by critics, and Poehler received an [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series|Emmy]] nomination for her role. NBC has since renewed ''Parks and Recreation'' for a fourth season. Poehler was featured in ''[[The Advocate]]'' for her role in the show.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Amy Poehler has also written two episodes of the series. The first being ''[[Telethon (Parks and Recreation)|Telethon]]'' in season 2, which was the episode Poehler sent in as her [[Emmy Awards]] submission in 2010. The second one is the episode entitled [[The Fight (Parks and Recreation)|''The Fight'']], which aired on May 12, 2011. Poehler was once again nominated for an Emmy AwardÂ - Oustanding Actress in a Comedy in 2011. She sent the episode [[Flu Season (Parks and Recreation)|''Flu Season'']] as her submission.{{fact|date=August 2011}} ===Film career and other work=== [[File:Amy Poehler and Tina Fey by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|[[Tina Fey]] and Poehler at the premiere of ''[[Baby Mama (film)|Baby Mama]]'' in New York.]] Poehler has appeared in the films ''[[Wet Hot American Summer]]'', ''[[Mean Girls]]'', ''[[Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo]]'', ''[[Tenacious D: The Pick of Destiny]]'', ''[[Blades of Glory]]'', ''[[Envy (2004 film)|Envy]]'', ''[[Shrek the Third]]'', ''[[Mr. Woodcock]]'', and ''[[Hamlet 2]]''. She is{{when|date=November 2010}} producing a digital series with two of her friends, Meredith Walker and [[Amy Miles]], ''Smart Girls at the Party'', available through ON Networks.[http://www.onnetworks.com/node/5445 ''Smart Girls at the Party''][http://www.onnetworks.com/ ON Networks] The show is focused on interviews with young women who are "changing the world by being themselves".[http://www.onnetworks.com/node/5445 Amy Poehler and Friends to Launch New Digital TV Show Aimed at âSmart Girlsâ and their Parents] The first season of 'Smart Girls at the Party' premiered online November 17, 2008, with Mattel's Barbie signed on as the lead sponsor.{{Cite news | url = http://news.tubefilter.tv/2008/11/14/amy-poehlers-smart-girls-kicks-off-with-mattels-barbie-on-board/ | title = Amy Poehlerâs âSmart Girlsâ Kicks Off With Mattelâs Barbie on Board | work=[[Tubefilter News]] | date = November 14, 2008 | accessdate = November 17, 2008}} She appeared in various comedy segments on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', often playing her recurring role as [[Andy Richter]]'s little sister Stacy, and as a recurring character in two episodes of the college dramedy ''[[Undeclared (TV show)|Undeclared]]''. She appears in the film ''[[Southland Tales]]'', which premiered on May 21, 2006 at the [[2006 Cannes Film Festival]]. In 2008, she appeared in ''[[Horton Hears a Who! (film)|Horton Hears a Who!]]'', ''[[Hamlet 2]]'', ''[[Baby Mama (film)|Baby Mama]]'', and ''[[Spring Breakdown]]''. She has also co-created an animated series for [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]] called ''[[The Mighty B!]]'', about Bessie Higgenbottom, a "sweet, merit-badge-obsessed girl scout", to which she lends her vocal talents.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/12/arts/television/12nick.html?ex=1323579600&en=fb73dfa9f88e330a&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss|title=SpongeBob SquareProfits: Nickelodeon Swears by Cartoons|last=Wyatt|first=Edward|date=December 12, 2006|work=The New York Times |accessdate=June 4, 2009}} In 2009, Poehler earned a Daytime Emmy nomination for Outstanding Performer in an Animated Series.{{cite news|url=http://news-briefs.ew.com/2009/05/14/daytime-emmy-aw/|title=Daytime Emmy Awards: 'One Life to Live', 'Ellen DeGeneres' top nominations|last=Bierly|first=Mandi|date=May 14, 2009|work=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=June 4, 2009}} In 2011 Poehler received the honor of being named one of TIME magazine's "100 most influential people in the world".[http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2066367_2066369_2066436,00.html "The 2011 TIME 100"] Time magazine She also delivered the Class Day address to [[Harvard University]]'s class of 2011.http://www.collegehumor.com/video/6514384/amy-poehlers-harvard-graduation-speech ==Personal life== Poehler married [[Will Arnett]] of the [[Fox Network|Fox]] comedy ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'' on August 29, 2003, and had a recurring role in the series as the [[List of recurring Arrested Development characters#Wife of Gob|nameless wife]] of Arnett's character [[George Oscar "G.O.B." Bluth II]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Poehler and Arnett also played a quasi-[[incest]]uous brother-sister ice skating team in the 2007 film ''[[Blades of Glory]]'', and appeared together in ''[[Horton Hears a Who! (film)|Horton Hears a Who!]]'', ''[[On Broadway (film)|On Broadway]]'', ''[[Spring Breakdown]]'', and ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'', along with Arnett having a guest appearance on Poehler's NBC comedy ''[[Parks and Recreation]]''. On October 25, 2008, Poehler gave birth to her first child, son Archibald William Emerson "Archie" Arnett, just hours before the ''Saturday Night Live'' telecast.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20235875,00.html|title=Amy Poehler Gives Birth to Baby Boy|last=Laudadio|first=Marisa |date=October 26, 2008|work=People |accessdate=October 26, 2008}} Poehler gave birth to her second son, Abel James Arnett, on August 6, 2010.{{cite news|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2010/08/06/amy-poehler-and-will-arnett-welcome-abel-james/|title=Amy Poehler and Will Arnett Welcome Son Abel James|first=Eunice|last=Oh|accessdate=August 6, 2010|date=August 6, 2010|publisher=Celebrity Babies}} She is a supporter of [[Planned Parenthood]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/270625/amys-pink-plea-kathryn-jean-lopez|title=Amyâs Pink Plea|first=Kathryn Jean|last=Lopez|accessdate=June 27, 2011|date=June 27, 2011|publisher=''[[National Review]]''}}{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1064465,00.html|title=10 Questions for Amy Poehler|first=Richard|last=Zoglin|accessdate=June 27, 2011|date=May 22, 2005|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine}} ==Filmography== [[File:Amy Poehler 2009 2.jpg|thumb|175px|Poehler at the premiere of ''[[Parks & Recreation (TV series)|Parks and Recreation]]'', April 9, 2009]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Nominated â [[Emmy Award|Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]] (2010, 2011) |- | 2010 || ''[[Megamind]]'' || Linda Prickles || rowspan="4"| Voice |- | rowspan="2"| 2011 || ''[[Hoodwinked 2: Hood vs. Evil]]'' || [[Hansel and Gretel|Gretel]] |- | ''[[Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chip-Wrecked]]'' || Eleanor |} ===Notable characters on ''SNL''=== * Amber, a one-legged [[hypoglycemia|hypoglycemic]] reality show contestant. * Betty Caruso, Bronx Beat co-host (opposite [[Maya Rudolph]]). * Kaitlin, the excitable preteen titular character of Kaitlin and Rick (opposite [[Horatio Sanz]]). * Netti Bo Dance, a frequent patient at the [[Appalachian Emergency Room]]. * Sally Needler, half of The Needlers, "the couple that should be divorced" (opposite [[Seth Meyers]]). * Zoe Anderton, the pun loving, David Beckham-obsessed [[Saturday Night Live TV show sketches#Spy Glass|Spy Glass]] co-host (opposite [[Seth Meyers]]). ===Impressions=== Poehler has impersonated [[Dakota Fanning]], [[Hillary Rodham Clinton]], [[Barbara Boxer]], [[Sharon Osbourne]], [[Britney Spears]], [[Paula Abdul]], [[Rosie O'Donnell]], [[Kelly Ripa]], [[Ann Coulter]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Avril Lavigne]], [[Sharon Stone]], [[Nancy Grace]], [[Michael Jackson]], [[Lindsay Lohan]], [[Christian Siriano]], [[Peter Ostrum]], [[David Spade]], [[Mr. Six]], [[Tonya Harding]], [[Dennis Kucinich]], [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]], [[Judy Garland]], [[J. K. Rowling]], [[Kim Jong-il]], [[Jenna Bush]], [[Katie Couric]], [[Tinker Bell]], and [[Rosie Perez]]. ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- style="text-align:center;"
